title: NaturalL2S: End-to-End High-quality Multispeaker Lip-to-Speech Synthesis with Differential Digital Signal Processing
author: Yifan Liang (not specified), Fangkun Liu (not specified), Andong Li (not specified), Xiaodong Li (not specified), Chengshi Zheng (not specified), Senior Member, IEEE (not specified)
relevance_why: The paper proposes an end-to-end framework for lip-to-speech synthesis which incorporates digital signal processing techniques. Haohe Liu's work in audio restoration and generation could benefit from the methodologies discussed in this paper, particularly regarding audio fidelity enhancements.
background: The task focuses on synthesizing intelligible speech from video of lip movements, enhancing speech quality through advanced processing techniques and machine learning models.
contribution: NaturalL2S introduces a Differentiable Digital Signal Processing synthesizer to solve the lip-to-speech synthesis problem, achieving improved speech quality and intelligibility.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically employed cascaded models, leading to issues with error propagation and speech quality degradation due to the reliance on intermediate representations (e.g., mel-spectrograms).
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating an end-to-end architecture with acoustic priors and a differentiable DSP synthesizer, reducing information loss and enhancing audio fidelity.

key_innovation: The integration of a Differentiable Digital Signal Processing synthesizer that captures both harmonic and aperiodic components for generating high-quality speech.
real_world_impact: Improving lip-to-speech technologies can significantly enhance communication tools for individuals with speech impairments and improve accessibility in visual media.
limitations: The authors do not explicitly mention limitations.

new_terms.Differentiable Digital Signal Processing: **Differentiable Digital Signal Processing** refers to a framework that combines traditional signal processing methods with deep learning to enable gradient-based learning of audio synthesizers, allowing for more flexible and interpretable audio signal generation.
